Title.evidence: Automatic Remifentanil Administration in Burn Surgery: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: 52 adult patients were randomised into two groups

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included ASA I–III patients scheduled for burn excision and skin grafts. Conducted at the Burn Center of the University Hospital of Lille, France

Intervention.evidence: automatic remifentanil infusion using the ANI-REMI-LOOP software or manual infusion (standard practice)

Objective.evidence: assessed the clinical efficacy and safety of an expert system for automatic remifentanil administration during propofol anesthesia in burn surgery

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the cumulative remifentanil dose during anesthesia

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using permutated blocks of four

Blinding.evidence: patients were blinded to group allocation

Number_Randomised.evidence: 52 adult patients were randomised into two groups: automatic remifentanil infusion using the ANI-REMI-LOOP software or manual infusion (standard practice). Conducted at the Burn Center of the University Hospital of Lille, France, from June 2018 to June 2022

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis was conducted on a per-protocol basis

Result_Outcome.evidence: The automatic group received a significantly lower cumulative remifentanil dose (0.125 µg.kg⁻¹.min⁻¹ [0.106 to 0.149]) compared to the manual group (0.152 µg.kg⁻¹.min⁻¹ [0.137 to 0.237], p = 0.004)

Harms.evidence: No adverse events related to the intervention were reported
